fields.title: Voyages and Applied History
fields.content:
Voyages and Applied history
Jelmer Vos (Emory University), 2007

The Voyages Database has the potential to be of value to those interested in current affairs, as well as to scholars involved in strictly academic research. One area where the database can be useful is the debate over the payment of reparations, monetary or otherwise, to descendants from the survivors of the Middle Passage. Other possible fields are those of business and family history. In this context, the database has helped to establish connections between the predecessors of a major international financial institution, the Dutch bank ABN AMRO, and African slavery in the Americas. It proved especially helpful in tracing the bank?s historical involvement in various financial aspects of the slave trade. Employing some of the database?s basic variables, we can see how the database can be used effectively in applied history, a joint endeavor in which historians collaborate to answer questions raised by other professionals.

In 2005-2006, at the direction of LaSalle Bank Corporation, at the time the U.S. subsidiary of ABN AMRO, History Associates Incorporated conducted a study of the Dutch bank?s predecessors to determine historical connections to African slavery in the United States and elsewhere in the Americas. In combination with archival research, the Voyages Database substantiated evidence that some of the bank?s predecessors provided insurance for slaving voyages, purchased interest in slaving voyages, or supplied credit to clients participating in the slave trade.

Logbooks at the Rotterdam municipal archives indicate that the Rotterdam banking firm of Chabot brokered insurance on cargo carried by the ship Vrouw Maria Isabella, commanded by Carsten Edebool, in 1774. The database confirmed that this vessel set out on a slaving voyage to Africa and Surinam (Voyage ID 10830). Moreover, comparing entries from the account books of the Mallet brothers with vessel names in the database, it was found that this French firm held interests in several vessels connected with the trans-Atlantic slave trade during the late 1700s. Examples of slaving vessels in which the Mallets had invested included the Infant d?Angole (owned by Renault and Dubois ), the Dame Cécile (owned by J. R. Wirtz and Company) as well as the Madame, Henri Quatre and Magdeleine (all owned by Delaville and Barthelemy). Similarly, the house of Mallet as well as another French predecessor, Banque André, had business dealings with numerous persons and firms which the database identified as outfitters of slaving voyages. For example, the Nantes houses of Ambroise Perrotin, Auguste Simon, and Fruchard Fils all received substantial loans from Mallet at the time they organized slaving voyages to Africa. Meantime, in 1819 the bank of André negotiated a loan of FF 15,000 with Vasse-Mancel from Le Havre, who five years later organized a slaving voyage to Senegal (Voyage ID 34411), while in 1823 they arranged payments on behalf of Philippon and Company from Le Havre for purchases in Liverpool for a slaving voyage to Brazil (Voyage ID 34376).

The study by History Associates made use of only three basic variables in the Voyages Database: vessel, captain, and owner names. Nevertheless, the database confirmed that important connections existed between the European world of high finance and the trans-Atlantic slave trade in the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.

fields.title: Viagens e história aplicada
fields.content:
Viagens e história aplicada
Jelmer Vos (Emory University), 2007

O Banco de Dados Viagens é potencialmente valioso para os interessados em assuntos atuais, bem como para os estudiosos envolvidos na pesquisa estritamente acadêmica. Uma área na qual o banco de dados pode ser útil é o debate sobre o pagamento de reparações, monetárias ou não, aos descendentes dos sobreviventes da travessia do Atlântico. Outros campos possíveis são a história das empresas e a das famílias. Nesse contexto, o banco de dados ajudou a estabelecer conexões entre os antecessores de uma grande instituição financeira internacional ? o banco holandês ABN AMRO ? e a escravidão africana nas Américas. Ele revelou-se particularmente útil ao levantar o envolvimento histórico do banco em diversos aspectos financeiros do tráfico de escravos. Ao fazer uso de algumas das variáveis básicas do banco de dados, podemos ver como ele pode ser utilizado de forma eficaz em história aplicada ? uma iniciativa em que historiadores colaboram para responder às questões levantadas por outros profissionais.

Em 2005-2006, sob a direção da LaSalle Bank Corporation ? na época, a subsidiária norte-americana do ABN AMRO ? a History Associates Incorporated realizou um estudo dos antecessores do banco holandês para determinar ligações históricas com a escravidão africana nos Estados Unidos e em outros países das Américas. Em combinação com pesquisas realizadas em arquivos, o Banco de Dados Viagens fundamentou provas de que alguns dos antecessores do banco forneceram seguros para viagens negreiras, tiveram participação em tais viagens ou abriram crédito pa ra clientes que participaram no tráfico de escravos.

Há diários de bordo nos arquivos municipais de Roterdã que indicam que a firma bancária Chabot, localizada na cidade, atuou como seguradora da carga transportada pelo navio Vrouw Maria Isabella, comandado por Carsten Edebool, em 1774. O banco de dados confirmou que esse navio partiu em uma viagem negreira, rumo à África e ao Suriname (Identidade de Viagem 10830). Além disso, comparando-se registros nos livros contábeis dos irmãos Mallet com os nomes dos navios que constam na base de dados, verificou-se que essa empresa francesa tinha participação em várias embarcações ligadas ao tráfico de escravos transatlântico durante o final do século XVIII. Entre os navios negreiros que receberam investimentos dos Mallets incluem-se o Infant d?Angole (de propriedade de Renault e Dubois), o Dame Cécile (de propriedade da JR Wirtz e Companhia), bem como o Madame, o Henri Quatre e o Magdeleine (todos de propriedade de Delaville e Barthelemy). Da mesma forma, a casa de Mallet e outro antecessor francês, o Banque André, negociavam com inúmeras pessoas e empresas identificadas pelo banco de dados como provedoras de viagens negreiras. Por exemplo, as casas Ambroise Perrotin, Auguste Simon e Fruchard Fils, de Nantes, receberam empréstimos substanciais de Mallet quando estavam organizando viagens negreiras para a África. Enquanto isso, em 1819, o André negociou um empréstimo de 15.000 francos com a Vasse-Mancel, de Le Havre, que cinco anos depois organizou uma viagem negreira para o Senegal (Identidade de Viagem 34411), e, em 1823, providenciou os pagamentos em nome de Philippon e Companhia, de Le Havre, para compras em Liverpool destinadas a uma viagem negreira para o Brasil (Identidade de Viagem 34376).

O estudo realizado pela History Associates fez uso de apenas três variáveis básicas do Banco de Dados Viagens: nomes de navios, capitães e proprietários. No entanto, o banco de dados confirmou que existiram conexões importantes entre o mundo europeu das altas finanças e o tráfico de escravos transatlântico no século XVIII e no início do século XIX.

fields.title: Viajes e Historia Aplicada
fields.content:
Viajes e Historia Aplicada
Jelmer Vos (Emory University), 2007

La base de datos Viajes puede ser de valor tanto para aquellos interesados en los asuntos de la actualidad como para estudiosos inmersos en la más estricta investigación académica. Un área en el que la base de datos es de gran utilidad es en el debate sobre el pago de indemnizaciones, monetarias o de otro tipo, a los descendientes de los sobrevivientes de la trata. Otras posibles áreas de interés es la de los negocios y la genealogía. En este contexto la base de datos ha ayudado a establecer conexiones entre los antecesores de una prominente institución financiera internacional, el banco holandés ABN AMRO, y la esclavitud en las Américas. Demostró ser de gran ayuda para indagar el involucramiento histórico del banco en los distintos aspectos financieros de la trata de esclavos. Mediante el empleo de algunas de las variables básicas de la base de datos podemos ver como esta puede ser usada de manera efectiva en la Historia Aplicada, una labor de conjunto en la que los historiadores colaboran para responder preguntas planteadas por otros profesionales.

En el año 2005-2006, bajo la dirección de LaSalle Bank Corporation, en aquel momento el subsidiario estadounidense de ABN AMRO, History Associates Incorporated condujo un estudio de los antecesores del banco holandés para determinar sus conexiones históricas con la esclavitud africana en los Estados Unidos y en las Américas en general. En combinación con la investigación de archivos la base de datos Viajes mostró evidencia de que algunos de los antecesores de este banco aseguraron viajes esclavistas, compraron interés en dichos viajes, o proporcionaron crédito a clientes que participaban en la trata de esclavos.

Los cuadernos de navegación del archivo municipal de Rotterdam indican que la firma bancaria de Rotterdam Chabot negoció seguros de carga para el barco Vrouw Maria Isabella, capitaneado por Carsten Edebool en 1774. La base de datos comprobó que este navío partió en un viaje esclavista hacia África y Surinam (número de identidad de viaje 10830.). Más aún, comparando las anotaciones en los libros de cuentas de los hermanos Mallet con los nombres de barcos en la base de datos se descubrió que esta firma francesa tenía intereses en varios barcos vinculados al comercio trasatlántico de esclavos a finales de 1700. Ejemplos de barcos esclavistas en los que los Mallet habían invertido incluían el Infant d?Angole (propiedad de Renault y Dubois), el Dame Cécile (propiedad de J. R. Wirtz and Company) así como el Madame, Henri Quatre y Magdeleine (todos siendo propiedad de Delaville y Barthelemy). Del mismo modo la casa de Mallet, así como otro antecesor francés, Banque André, tenían negocios con numerosas personas y firmas que la base de datos identificó como organizadores de viajes de esclavos. Por ejemplo, las casas de Ambroise Perrotin, Auguste Simon, y Fruchard Fils de Nantes todos recibieron jugosos préstamos de Mallet al tiempo que organizaban viajes a África. Mientras tanto en 1819 el banco de André negoció un préstamo de FF 15,000 con Vasse-Mancel de Le Havre quien cinco años más tarde organizó un viaje esclavista a Senegal ((número de identificación de viaje 34411), mientras que en 1823 tramitaron pagos a nombre de Philippon and Company de Le Havre para compras hechas en Liverpool para un viaje esclavista a Brasil (número de identificación de viaje 34376).

El estudio realizado por History Associates hizo uso solamente de tres variables básicas en la base de datos Viajes: barco, capitán y nombres de los dueños. Sin embargo, la base de datos ratificó que existían vínculos importantes entre el mundo de las grandes finanzas europeo y el comercio trasatlántico de esclavos en los siglos dieciocho y diecinueve.

fields.title: Full Versions of the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade Database
fields.content:
Full Versions of the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade Database

The 2018 version of the transatlantic slave trade database contains 36,001 voyages compared to 34,940 in 2008 (and 27,233 in the 1999 version of the database that appeared on CD-ROM). Since 2008, several thousand corrections have been made and additional information added. Thus 280 of the 2008 voyages have been deleted either because we found they had been entered twice, or because we discovered that a voyage was not involved in the transatlantic slave trade. For example voyage id 16772, the Pye, Captain Adam, turned out to have carried slaves from Jamaica to the Chesapeake, but obtained its captives in Jamaica, not Africa. Offsetting the deletions are 1,341 voyages added on the basis of new information. Further, many voyages that are common to both 2008 and 2018 versions of the database now contain information that was not available in 2008 (see table 1 of “Understanding the Database” for the current summary). The 2016 version has 274 variables, compared with 98 in the Voyages Database available online. Users interested in working with this larger data set can download it in a file formatted for use with SPSS software. Because some users may find it useful to view data as it existed in earlier versions, the database as it was in 1999, 2008 and 2010 can also be selected for download. A codebook describing all variable names, variable labels, and values of the expanded dataset is available as a separate Word document. With only a few exceptions, it retains variable names in the original 1999 CD-ROM version

The 2010 version of the transatlantic slave trade database contains 35,941 voyages compared to 34,940 in 2008 (and 27,233 in the 1999 version of the database that appeared on CD-ROM). However, since 2008, several hundred corrections have been made and additional information added. Offsetting the deletions are 94 voyages added on the basis of new information. Further many voyages that are common to both 2008 and 2010 versions of the database contain information that was not available in 2008 (see table 1 of ?Understanding the Database?). The 2010 version has 276 variables, compared with 99 in the Voyages Database available online. Users interested in working with this larger data set can download it in a file formatted for use with SPSS software. A variable in this dataset (EVGREEN) identifies voyages on the CD-ROM version published in 1999. A codebook describing all variable names, variable labels, and values of the expanded dataset can be downloaded as a separate PDF document. With only a few exceptions, it retains variable names in the original 1999 CD-ROM version. The 2008 version of the database may also be downloaded.

fields.title: Estimates Datasets and Supplementary Documents
fields.content:
Datasets and Supplementary Documents

The Estimates section uses data from the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade Database dataset, aggregated by regions of embarkation and disembarkation, but also incorporates published series of embarkations and disembarkations for particular regions when these data provide more accurate estimates than the database itself. Users interested in exploring the complex methodology involved in generating the estimates, or in testing the extent to which alternative assumptions lower or augment estimates of the full volume of the slave trade (in its entirety or for a national carrier or period of time), can download below an Excel-formatted copy of the spreadsheet estimating the full volume of the slave trade by national carrier and year of arrival, the SPSS file applying estimates of volume in the spreadsheet to data on exports and imports aggregated by national carrier, year of arrival, and the route of the voyage from region of embarkation to region of disembarkation, and a PDF version of the essay detailing the methodology used. New estimates of the pre-1640 traffic to Spanish America can be found in Alex Borucki, David Eltis and David Wheat. “Atlantic History and the Slave Trade to Spanish America,” American Historical Review, 120 (2015): 433-461, supplementary notes and an additional spreadsheet for which appear below. For further discussion of the validity of our overall estimates see David Eltis and Paul Lachance, “Comments on Patrick Manning, Yun Zhang, and Bowen Yi, ‘Volume and Direction of the Atlantic Slave Trade, 1650-1870,’” Journal of World Historical Information, 2 (2014-15): 150-53, an appendix to which is the final document in this panel.

fields.title: African Names Database
fields.content:
African Names Database

This database contains personal information of 91,491 Africans taken from captured slave ships or from African slave trading sites after 1807 as a result of the British navy?s attempt to suppress the slave trade. It includes names, stature, sex/age category, country of origin, the name and database id of the slave vessel involved, year of arrival, and ports of embarkation and disembarkation. These variables may be searched on the African Names Database page of the present site. They have also been incorporated into African-Origins.org that provides in addition opportunities to view and contribute to the ethnolinguistic identification of the African names.

fields.content:
Base de datos de nombres africanos
 
Esta base de datos contiene información personal de 91,491 africanos tomados de los barcos capturados o de sitios de tráfico de esclavos africanos después de 1807 como resultado de los intentos de la marina británica por suprimir el tráfico de esclavos. Incluye nombres, estatura, categoría sexo/edad, país de origen, el nombre y los datos del navío involucrado, el año de arribo y lo puertos de embarque y desembarque. Estas variables pueden ser investigadas en la página de Datos de nombres africanos de este sitio. También han sido incorporadas en African-Origins.org que adicionalmente provee oportunidades para ver y contribuir a la identificación etnolingüística de los nombres africanos.

fields.title: Introductory Maps
fields.content:
Introductory Maps

Source: David Eltis and David Richardson, Atlas of the Transatlantic Slave Trade (New Haven, 2010), reproduced with the permission of Yale University Press. For permission to reuse these images, contact Yale University Press.

 
View in Original Size
Map 1: Overview of the slave trade out of Africa, 1500-1900

Captive Africans followed many routes from their homelands to other parts of the world. The map shows the trans-Atlantic movement of these captives in comparative perspective for the centuries since 1500 only. Estimates of the ocean-borne trade are more robust than are those for the trans-Saharan, Red Sea and Persian Gulf routes, but it is thought that for the period from the end of the Roman Empire to 1900 about the same number of captives crossed the Atlantic as left Africa by all other routes combined.

 
View in Original Size
Map 2: Migration of sugar cultivation from Asia into the Atlantic

Sugar cultivation began in the Pacific in the pre-Christian era and gradually spread to the eastern Mediterranean, the Gulf of Guinea, then to Brazil, before entering the Caribbean in the mid-seventeenth century. Eighty percent of all captives carried from Africa were taken to sugar-growing areas.

 
View in Original Size
Map 3: Old World slave trade routes in the Atlantic before 1759

Before the Atlantic slave trade began and for two centuries thereafter, some African captives were taken to Europe as well as to the Atlantic islands and between African ports. It is hard to get precise estimates of these flows, but they were certainly much smaller than the trans-Atlantic traffic. Many of the captives involved in this traffic were subsequently carried to sugar plantations in the Old World.

 
View in Original Size
Map 4: Wind and ocean currents of the Atlantic basins

In the age of sail, winds and ocean currents shaped the direction of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, effectively creating two separate slave-trading systems ? one in the north with voyages originating in Europe and North America, the other in the south with voyages originating in Brazil.

 
View in Original Size
Map 5: Major regions and ports involved in the trans-Atlantic slave trade, all years

Few commercial centers in the Atlantic world were untouched by the slave trade, and all the major ports had strong connections with the traffic.

 
View in Original Size
Map 6: Countries and regions in the Atlantic World where slave voyages were organized, by share of captives carried off from Africa

Slave voyages were organized and left from all major Atlantic ports at some point over the nearly four centuries of the trans-Atlantic slave trade. Nevertheless, vessels from the largest seven ports, Rio de Janeiro, Bahia, Liverpool, London, Nantes, Bristol, and Pernambuco carried off almost three-quarters of all captives removed from Africa via the Atlantic Ocean. There was a major shift in the organization of slaving voyages first from the Iberian peninsular to Northern Europe, and then later back again to ports in southern Europe. A similar, but less pronounced shift may be observed in the Americas from South to North and then back again.

Total documented embarkations: 8,973,701 captives
Percent of estimated embarkations: 72.1%

 
View in Original Size
Map 7: Major coastal regions from which captives left Africa, all years

The limits of the regions shown here are ?Senegambia,? anywhere north of the Rio Nunez. Sierra Leone region comprises the Rio Nunez to just short of Cape Mount. The Windward Coast is defined as Cape Mount south-east to and including the Assini river. The Gold Coast runs east of here up to and including the Volta River. Bight of Benin covers the Rio Volta to Rio Nun, and the Bight of Biafra, east of the Nun to Cape Lopez inclusive. West-central Africa is defined as the rest of the western coast of the continent south of this point, and south-eastern Africa anywhere from and to the north and east of the Cape of Good Hope. West-Central Africa was the largest regional departure point for captives through most the slave trade era. Regions closer to the Americas and Europe generated a relatively small share of the total carried across the Atlantic. Voyage length was determined as much by wind and ocean currents shown in Map 4 as by relative proximity of ports of embarkation and disembarkation.

Total documented embarkations: 7,878,500 captives
Percent of estimated embarkations: 63.3%

 
View in Original Size
Map 8: Major regions where captives disembarked, all years

The Caribbean and South America received 95 percent of the slaves arriving in the Americas. Some captives disembarked in Africa rather than the Americas because their trans-Atlantic voyage was diverted as a result of a slave rebellion or, during the era of suppression, because of capture by patrolling naval cruisers. Less than 4 percent disembarked in North America, and only just over 10,000 in Europe.

Total documented embarkations: 9,371,001 captives
Percent of estimated embarkations: 88.5%

 
View in Original Size
Map 9: Volume and direction of the trans-Atlantic slave trade from all African to all American regions

This map summarizes and combines the many different paths by which captives left Africa and reached the Americas. While there were strong connections between particular embarkation and disembarkation regions, it was also the case that captives from any of the major regions of Africa could disembark in almost any of the major regions of the Americas. Even captives leaving Southeast Africa, the region most remote from the Americas, could disembark in mainland North America, as well as the Caribbean and South America. The data in this map are based on estimates of the total slave trade rather than documented departures and arrivals.

This map summarizes and combines the many different paths by which captives left Africa and reached the Americas. While there were strong connections between particular embarkation and disembarkation regions, it was also the case that captives from any of the major regions of Africa could disembark in almost any of the major regions of the Americas. Even captives leaving Southeast Africa, the region most remote from the Americas, could disembark in mainland North America, as well as the Caribbean and South America. fields.title: Mapas introductorios
fields.content:
Mapas introductorios

Fuente: David Eltis y David Richardson,  Atlas of the Transatlantic Slave Trade  (New Haven, 2010), reproducido con el consentimiento de Yale University Press. Para obtener permiso para reusar estas imágenes contacte Yale University Press.

 

 

View in Original Size
Mapa 1: Resumen del comercio de esclavos desde África, 1500-1900

Los cautivos africanos siguieron muchas rutas desde su tierra hacia otras partes del mundo. Este mapa muestra el trayecto trasatlántico de estos cautivos desde una perspectiva comparada por los siglos a partir de 1500 solamente. Los estimados del comercio oceánico son más robustos que los del comercio a través del Sahara, del Mar Rojo y de las rutas del Golfo Pérsico, pero se piensa que para el período que abarca desde la caída del imperio romano hasta 1900 el número de cautivos que cruzó el Atlántico desde África era aproximadamente el mismo combinando todas las rutas.

 

View in Original Size
Mapa 2: Traslado del cultivo de azúcar desde Asia hasta el Atlántico

El cultivo de azúcar comenzó en el Pacífico en la era precristiana y de manera gradual se extendió al este del Mediterráneo, el golfo de Guinea, después a Brasil antes de entrar al Caribe a mediados del siglo XVII. Ochenta por ciento de todos los cautivos traídos de África fueron llevados a regiones azucareras.

 

View in Original Size
Mapa 3: Rutas de comercio de esclavos del Viejo Mundo en el Atlántico antes de 1759

Antes de que comenzara el comercio de esclavos y por dos siglos consecutivos, algunos cautivos africanos eran llevados a Europa, así como a islas del Atlántico y también a puertos africanos. Es difícil obtener estimaciones exactas de este flujo, pero sin lugar a duda era un número mucho menor que el del tráfico trasatlántico. Muchos de los cautivos envueltos en este tráfico fueron consecutivamente llevados a plantaciones de azúcar en el Viejo Mundo.

 

View in Original Size
Mapa 4: Vientos y corrientes marítimas en la cuenca Atlántica

En la era de la navegación los vientos y corrientes oceánicas definieron la dirección del tráfico trasatlántico de esclavos, creando dos sistemas de comercio de esclavos -uno en el Atlántico norte con viajes que se originaban en Europa y Norteamérica y el otro en el Atlántico sur con viajes originados en Brasil.

 

View in Original Size
Mapa 5: Principales regiones y puertos envueltos en el comercio trasatlántico de esclavos, todos los años

Muy pocos centros de comercio en el mundo atlántico quedaron a salvo del mercado de esclavos y todos los puertos principales tenían fuertes vínculos con el tráfico.

 

View in Original Size
Mapa 6: Regiones y países del mundo Atlántico donde se organizaron los viajes de esclavos, según el número de cautivos transportados desde África

Los viajes de esclavos eran organizados y partían de los principales puertos del Atlántico durante los casi cuatro siglos del comercio trasatlántico de esclavos. Sin embargo, navíos procedentes de los siete puertos principales, Rio de Janeiro, Bahia, Liverpool, London, Nantes, Bristol y Pernambuco llevaron casi tres cuartos de todos los cautivos removidos de África por vía del Océano Atlántico. Hubo un cambio significativo en la organización de viajes esclavistas primeramente desde la península ibérica hacia el norte de Europa y luego de regreso a los puertos al sur de Europa. Un cambio similar, pero menos pronunciado se puede observar en las Américas del sur al norte y viceversa.

Número total de embarques documentados: 8,973,701 cautivos.

Por ciento de embarques estimados: 72.1 %.

 

View in Original Size
Mapa 7: Principales regiones costeras desde donde partían los cautivos en África, todos los años

Los límites de las regiones que se muestran aquí son “Senegambia”, desde el norte del río Núñez. La región de Sierra Leona comprende el río Núñez hasta poco antes de Cape Mount. La costa de Barlovento se define desde sureste de Cape Mount hasta incluir el río Assini. La Costa de Oro corre al este desde allí hacia e incluyendo el río Volta. La ensenada de Benín abarca desde el río Volta al río Nun, y la ensenada de Biafra al este de Nun hasta incluir Cabo López. África Centro-Occidental se define como el resto de la costa occidental del continente al sur de este punto, y África sur oriental de cualquier parte desde y hasta el norte y este del cabo de Buena Esperanza. África Centro-Occidental fue el mayor punto de partida de cautivos durante la mayor parte de la era del comercio esclavista. Regiones que eran más cercanas a las Américas y Europa generaban una cuota relativamente pequeña del total transportado a través del Atlántico. El largo de la travesía era determinado en gran medida por los vientos y corrientes oceánicas que se muestran en el mapa 4 así como también la proximidad relativa de puertos de embarque y desembarque.

Número total de embarques documentados: 7, 878,500 cautivos.

Por ciento de embarques estimados: 63.3 %

 

View in Original Size
Mapa 8: Principales regiones donde desembarcaban los cautivos, todos los años

El Caribe, México, América Central y Sudamérica recibieron el 95 por ciento de los esclavos que llegaban a las Américas. Algunos cautivos desembarcaban en África en lugar de las Américas porque su viaje trasatlántico se desviaba como resultado de una rebelión de esclavos, o durante la era de la supresión debido a la captura y patrulla por parte de los cruceros navales. Menos del 4 por ciento desembarcó en lo que se convertiría en Estados Unidos y un poco más de 10.000 solamente en Europa.

Número total de embarques documentados: 9,371,001 cautivos.

Por ciento de embarques estimados: 88.5 %

 
View in Original Size
Mapa 9: Volumen y trayectoria del comercio trasatlántico de esclavos desde todas las regiones africanas hacia todas las regiones americanas

Este mapa resume y combina las diferentes rutas a través de las cuales los cautivos dejaban África y llegaban a las Américas. Si bien había fuerte conexión entre regiones de embarque y desembarque específicas, también ocurría que los cautivos de cualquier de las principales regiones de África podían desembarcar en cualquiera de las principales regiones de las Américas. Hasta cautivos que dejaban el sureste de África, la región más lejos de las Américas, podían desembarcar en el continente de Norteamérica, así como también del Caribe y Suramérica. La información en este mapa se basa en los estimados del comercio de esclavos en su totalidad en lugar de partidas y arribos documentados.

fields.title: African Names Database
fields.content:
African Names Database

During the last 60 years of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, courts around the Atlantic basins condemned over two thousand vessels for engaging in the traffic and recorded the details of captives found on board including their African names. The African Names Database was created from these records, now located in the Registers of Liberated Africans at the Sierra Leone National Archives, Freetown, as well as Series FO84, FO313, CO247 and CO267 held at the British National Archives in London. Links are provided to the ships in the Voyages Database from which the liberated Africans were rescued, as well as to the African Origins site where users can hear the names pronounced and help us identify the languages in which they think the names are used.

fields.title: African Names Database
fields.content:
African Names Database

During the last 60 years of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, courts around the Atlantic basins condemned over two thousand vessels for engaging in the traffic and recorded the details of captives found on board including their African names. The African Names Database was created from these records, now located in the Registers of Liberated Africans at the Sierra Leone National Archives, Freetown, as well as Series FO84, FO313, CO247 and CO267 held at the British National Archives in London. Links are provided to the ships in the Voyages Database from which the liberated Africans were rescued, as well as to the African Origins site where users can hear the names pronounced and help us identify the languages in which they think the names are used.

fields.title: Base de datos de nombres africanos
fields.content:
Base de datos de nombres africanos

Durante los últimos 60 años del tráfico trasatlántico, algunos tribunales alrededor de la cuenca Atlántica expropiaron más de dos mil barcos por participar en la trata y documentaron los detalles de los cautivos a bordo, incluyendo sus nombres africanos. La Base de datos de nombres africanos ha sido creada con información tomada de estos documentos, que en el presente se encuentran en los Registros de africanos liberados en los Archivos Nacionales de Sierra Leona en Freetown, así como también en las Series FO84, FO313, CO247 y CO267 que se encuentran en los Archivos Nacionales de Gran Bretaña en Londres. Del mismo modo se provee enlaces a los registros en la base de datos Viajes con los barcos de donde los africanos fueron liberados, así como al sitio web de los Orígenes africanos, en el que los usuarios pueden escuchar la pronunciación de los nombres y auxiliar a la identificación de los idiomas en los que se encuentran dichos nombres.

fields.title: Lesson Plans
fields.content:
Lesson Plans

In order to present the trans-Atlantic slave trade database to a broader audience, particularly a grade 6-12 audience, a dedicated team of teachers and curriculum developers from around the United States developed lesson plans that explore the database. Utilizing the various resources of the website, these lessons plans allow students to engage the history and legacy of the Atlantic slave trade in diverse and meaningful ways. The lessons are all aligned with national standards in history (National Center for History in the Schools), social studies (National Council for the Social Studies), and geography (National Council for Geography Education) and range in both their grade levels and activities. The lessons also suggest readings for more information about the Slave Trade.

These materials were created for purposes of curriculum and instruction and are not intended for commercial republication. Please contact individual authors for additional permissions.

fields.title: Planos de Aula
fields.content:
Planos de Aula

A fim de apresentar o banco de dados do tráfico de escravos transatlântico para um público mais amplo, especialmente na faixa de 6 a 12 anos de idade, uma dedicada equipe de professores e elaboradores de currículos de todos os Estados Unidos desenvolveu planos de aula que exploram o banco de dados. Utilizando os diversos recursos do website, esses planos de aula permitem que os alunos explorem a história e o legado do tráfico de escravos atlântico em diversas formas relevantes. As aulas estão todas alinhadas com as normas norte-americanas de história (National Center for History in the Schools), ciências sociais (National Council for the Social Studies) e geografia (National Council for Geography Education), e variam tanto em relação à série escolar quanto ao tipo de atividade. Elas também sugerem leituras para se obterem mais informações sobre o tráfico de escravos.

Estes materiais foram criados para fins de currículo e instrução e não se destinam a republicação comercial. Entre em contato com os autores individuais para obter permissões adicionais.

fields.title: Planes de estudio
fields.content:
Planes de estudio

Con el fin de presentar la Base de datos del tráfico trasatlántico de esclavos ante un público más amplio, especialmente los estudiantes de sexto año a doce de los Estados Unidos, un equipo especializado de maestros y expertos en currículo de este país ha diseñado una serie de unidades didácticas para explorar la base de datos. Haciendo uso de las diversas herramientas que provee el sitio web, estas unidades de estudio permiten al estudiante comprender la historia y el legado del tráfico trasatlántico de esclavos de manera significativa. Las lecciones están en concordancia con los estándares nacionales para el estudio de la Historia trazados por el Centro Nacional para la enseñanza escolar de la Historia (National Center for History in the Schools), los estándares para el estudio de las Ciencias Sociales establecidos por el Consejo Nacional para el estudio de las Ciencias Sociales (National Council for the Social Studies) y de la enseñanza de la Geografía establecidos por el Consejo Nacional para la enseñanza de la Geografía (National Council for Geographic Education). Las actividades concuerdan con los distintos grados escolares. También se sugieren lecturas adicionales sobre la trata.

Estos materiales fueron creados para la enseñanza de un currículo y no para reedición comercial. Para autorización adicional favor de contactar a los autores individuales.

Los sitios web listados aquí proveen una variedad de recursos, que incluyen actividades educativas, mapas interactivos, y narrativas de africanos esclavizados. Hemos mantenido los enlances a estos sitios en su idioma original.

fields.title: The 1808 Slave Trade Abolition Deadline
fields.content:
The 1808 Slave Trade Abolition Deadline (Download, PDF )
Author: Heather Dahl
Grade Level: 10th ? 12th grade
Course: US History, US Government
Key Words:Abolition; Slave Trade; United States; Primary Sources; Graph skills
Standards
  • NCHS History Standards
    • US Era 2 (Colonization and Settlement) Standard 3
    • US Era 4 (Expansion and Reform) Standards 2 and 4
  • NCSS Social Studies Themes
    • II Time, Continuity, Change
    • IV Individual Development and Identity
  • Geography
    • World in Spatial Terms Standard 1
    • Human Systems Standard 9
Abstract
In this lesson, students will examine the data of the trans-Atlantic slave trade and primary sources related to the slave trade. The data will easily reveal to students a steep incline before 1808 and, in fact, a continuation of imported enslaved Africans after the slave trade was abolished in the United States and Great Britain. Students will also examine perspectives on slavery, as the deadline for ending the slave trade approached and passed. The lesson allows students to develop their own conclusions about both the intention and impact of the 1808 deadline on the overall history of slavery.

fields.title: O prazo para a abolição do tráfico de escravos em 1808
fields.content:
O prazo para a abolição do tráfico de escravos em 1808 (Download, PDF )
Autor: Heather Dahl
Séries: 10th ? 12th grade
Curso: História dos Estados Unidos, Governo dos Estados Unidos
Palavras-chave:Abolição; Tráfico de Escravos; Estados Unidos; Fontes Primárias; Uso de Gráficos
Normas
  • Normas de História do NCHS
    • Era 2 dos EUA (Colonização e Povoamento) Norma 3
    • Era 4 dos EUA (Expansão e Reforma) Normas 2 e 4
  • Temas de Ciências Sociais do NCSS
    • II Tempo, Continuidade, Mudança
    • IX Conexões Globais
  • Geografia
    • O Mundo em Termos Espaciais Norma 1
    • Sistemas Humanos Norma 9
Resumo
Nesta aula, os alunos irão analisar os dados do tráfico de escravos transatlântico e as fontes primárias relacionadas com o tráfico de escravos. Os dados facilmente revelarão aos estudantes um aumento acentuado antes de 1808 e a continuação da importação de escravos africanos depois da abolição do tráfico de escravos nos Estados Unidos e na Grã-Bretanha. Os alunos também examinarão perspectivas sobre a escravidão, como a aproximação e o fim da data limite para o encerramento do tráfico de escravos. A lição permite aos alunos desenvolverem as suas próprias conclusões sobre a intenção e o impacto do prazo final de 1808 na história geral da escravidão.

fields.title: El plazo para la abolición del comercio de esclavos de 1808
fields.content:
El plazo para la abolición del comercio de esclavos de 1808 (Descargar, PDF )
Autor: Heather Dahl
Nivel académico: 10th ? 12th grade
Curso: Historia de Estados Unidos, Gobierno de los Estados Unidos
Palabras clave:Abolición; comercio de esclavos; Estados Unidos; fuentes primarias; uso de gráficos
Estándares
  • Estándares de Historia del NCHS
    • Era 2 de EUA (Colonización y Asentamiento) Estándar 3
    • Era 4 de EUA (Expansión y Reforma) Estándares 2 y 4
  • Temas de Ciencias Sociales del NCSS
    • II Tiempo, Continuidad, Cambio
    • IV Desarrollo individual e identidad
  • Geografía
    • El mundo en términos espaciales estándar 1
    • Sistemas humanos estándar 9
Resumen
En esta lección los estudiantes examinarán la información sobre el comercio trasatlántico de esclavos y las fuentes primarias relacionadas con el tráfico de esclavos. Esta información les revelará inmediatamente un incremento pronunciado antes de 1808 y, en efecto, una continuación de la importación de esclavos africanos después que la trata fue abolida en los Estados Unidos y Gran Bretaña. Los estudiantes también explorarán perspectivas sobre la esclavitud en lo que el plazo para terminar el tráfico de esclavos se acercaba y terminaba. La lección les permite a los estudiantes desarrollar sus propias conclusiones acerca de la intención y el impacto de este plazo de 1808 en la historia de la esclavitud en general.

fields.title: One Country's Slave Trade
fields.content:
One Country?s Slave Trade (Download, PDF )
Author: Kristine Leach
Grade Level: 6th ? 8th grade
Course: Social Studies
Key Words:Slave Trade; Graph and Map skills
Standards
  • NCHS History Standards
    • US Era 2 (Colonization and Settlement) Standard 3
    • US Era 4 (Expansion and Reform) Standards 2 and 4
  • NCSS Social Studies Themes
    • II Time, Continuity, Change
    • IV Individual Development and Identity
  • Geography
    • World in Spatial Terms Standard 1
    • Human Systems Standard 9
Abstract
This lesson focuses students on one specific country that participated in the slave trade. Students will gather information from the database to document the slave trade for the country they have chosen and will then look at specific data, such as the numbers of enslaved people transported during different time periods and the areas of embarkation and disembarkation. This lesson offers students a more detailed example of the slave trade than would an overview of the slave trade.

fields.title: One Country's Slave Trade
fields.content:
One Country?s Slave Trade (Download, PDF )
Autor: Kristine Leach

Curso: Estudos Sociais

Resumo
Esta aula se concentra em um país específico que participou do tráfico de escravos. Os alunos coletarão informações do banco de dados para documentar o tráfico de escravos do país que escolheram e olharão em seguida para dados específicos, tais como os números de pessoas escravizadas transportadas durante diferentes períodos de tempo e as áreas de embarque e desembarque. A aula oferece aos alunos um exemplo mais detalhado do tráfico de escravos do que uma visão geral poderia oferecer.

fields.title: El Tráfico de Esclavos en Estados Unidos

El Tráfico de Esclavos en Estados Unidos  (Descargar, PDF )

Estándares

Resumen
Esta lección enfoca a los estudiantes en un país específico que haya participado en la trata de esclavos. Los estudiantes obtendrán información de la base de datos para documentar el comercio de esclavos del país que hayan seleccionado y entonces examinarán información específica tal como el número de personas esclavizadas transportadas durante diferentes periodos y las zonas de embarque y desembarque. Esta lección les ofrece a los estudiantes un ejemplo más detallado del tráfico de esclavos que aquel que se puede encontrar en una reseña de la trata esclavista.

fields.title: The Countries of the Slave Trade
fields.content:
The Countries of the Slave Trade (Download, PDF )
Author: Kristine Leach
Grade Level: 6th ? 8th grade
Course: Social Studies
Key Words:Slave Trade; Nations; Middle Passage; Graph skills
Standards
  • NCHS History Standards
    • US Era 2 (Colonization and Settlement) Standard 1A
    • World Era 6 (First Global Age) Standard 4B
Abstract
This lesson is a comparative look at the number of enslaved people transported by each of the seven flag countries listed on the database and also an examination of the ordeal of the Middle Passage. Students will gain an understanding of the immensity of the international slave trade but will also focus on the human experience of the Middle Passage.

fields.title: Os Países do Tráfico de Escravos
fields.content:
Os Países do Tráfico de Escravos (Download, PDF )
Autor: Kristine Leach

  • Normas de História do NCHS
    • Era 2 dos EUA (Colonização e Povoamento) Norma 1A
    • Era 6 do Mundo (Primeira Idade Global) Norma 4B

Esta aula é uma visão comparativa do número de pessoas escravizadas transportadas sob cada uma das sete bandeiras de países listados no banco de dados, e também um exame do sofrimento durante a travessia do Atlântico. Os alunos não só irão adquirir uma compreensão da enormidade do tráfico de escravos internacional, como também se concentrarão na experiência humana da travessia do Atlântico.

fields.title: Los países del comercio de esclavos

Los países del comercio de esclavos (Descargar, PDF )

Esta lección es una visión comparativa del número de personas esclavizadas transportadas por cada uno de los siete países con banderas registrados en la base de datos, así como también un análisis de la agonía de la Travesía Intermedia. Los estudiantes alcanzarán una comprensión de la inmensidad del comercio internacional de esclavos, pero también se concentrarán en la experiencia humana de la Travesía Intermedia.

fields.title: Slave Trade Memorial
fields.content:
Slave Trade Memorial (Download, PDF ) (Download Presentation, PPT, )
Author: Michael Poreda
Grade Level: 6th ? 8th grade
Course: US History, World History
Key Words:Slave Trade; Memorial; Middle Passage; Mortality Rates; Writing skills
Standards
  • NCHS History Standards
    • US Era 2 (Colonization and Settlement)
    • World Era 6 (First Global Age)
  • NCSS Social Studies Themes
    • IX Global Connections
    • X Civic Ideals and Practices
Abstract
This lesson asks students to demonstrate mastery of their knowledge about the Middle Passage by designing a memorial. The lesson contains several steps which teachers can use at their discretion to build an appreciation for what enslaved Africans were subjected to as they were forced to the New World, why this part of history should get a public memorial, and how that memorial should be expressed in words and image. The lesson uses mortality statistics from the database to help students gain an understanding of how many people died on a voyage, as well as reading comprehension questions and a PowerPoint Presentation of various monuments.

fields.title: Memorial do Tráfico de Escravos
fields.content:
Memorial do Tráfico de Escravos (Download, PDF ) (Download Apresentação, PPT, )
Autor: Michael Poreda
Séries: 6th ? 8th grade
Curso: História dos EUA, História do Mundo

Normas

    • Era 6 do Mundo (Primeira Era Global)
  • Temas de Ciências Sociais do NCSS
    • IX Global Connections
    • X Ideais e Práticas Cívicas
Resumo
Esta aula exige dos alunos que demonstrem que dominam o tema da travessia do Atlântico projetando um memorial. A aula apresenta várias etapas que os professores podem utilizar a seu modo, a fim de levar os alunos a compreender o que os africanos escravizados eram obrigados a suportar quando trazidos à força para o Novo Mundo, por que esta parte da história merece um memorial público, e como esse memorial deve ser expresso em palavras e imagens. A aula utiliza estatísticas de mortalidade do banco de dados para ajudar os alunos a terem uma noção do número de pessoas que morreram em uma viagem, bem como questões de compreensão de texto e uma apresentação de PowerPoint de vários monumentos.

fields.title: Memorial del comercio de esclavos
fields.content:
Memorial del comercio de esclavos (Descargar, PDF ) (Descargue presentación, PPT, )
Autor: Michael Poreda
Nivel académico: 6th ? 8th grade
Curso: Historia de EUA, Historia Mundial

Estándares

Resumen
Esta lección pide a los estudiantes demostrar su conocimiento de la Travesía Intermedia mediante el diseño de un memorial. La lección contiene varios pasos que los maestros pueden usar como mejor estimen para inculcar un reconocimiento y aprecio de lo que los africanos esclavizados sufrieron mientras eran forzados a viajar al Nuevo Mundo, por qué esta parte de la historia merece un memorial público y que palabras e imágenes deben usarse. Esta lección emplea las estadísticas de mortalidad de la base de datos para ayudar a los estudiantes a alcanzar un entendimiento de cuantos murieron en el viaje, así como también preguntas de comprensión de lectura y una presentación PowerPoint de varios monumentos.

fields.title: Finding Historical Evidence
fields.content:
Finding Historical Evidence (Download, PDF )
Author: Brian Hamilton
Grade Level: 11th ? 12th grade
Course: AP World History; African and African-American St
Key Words:Slave Trade; Slavery; Historical arguments; Evaluating evidence
Standards
  • NCHS History Standards
    • US Era 1 (Three Worlds Meet) Standards 1 & 2
    • World Era 6 (First Global Age) Standards 1A, 1B, 2A, 4A, 4B, 4C, & 6
  • NCSS Social Studies Themes
    • I Culture
    • II Time, Continuity, Change
    • III People, Places, Environments
    • V Individual, Groups, Institutions
    • VI Power, Authority, Governance
    • VII Production, Distribution, Consumption
    • IX Global Connections
  • Geography
    • World in Spatial Terms Standards 1-3
    • Places and Regions Standards 4-6
    • Human Systems Standards 9-13
    • Issues of Geography Standard 17
Abstract
This lesson puts equal emphasis on the history of the trans-Atlantic slave trade and on the craft of forming historical arguments. Students are asked to read a recent work from David Brion Davis, a leading historian of slavery, and to compare his arguments with evidence from the database. This forms the foundation for a discussion of what kinds of claims are harder to defend than others and why some types of evidence are more convincing than others.

fields.title: Como Encontrar Dados Históricos
fields.content:
Como Encontrar Dados Históricos (Download, PDF )
Autor: Brian Hamilton

Resumo
Esta aula dá igual ênfase à história do tráfico de escravos transatlântico e ao ofício de elaborar argumentações históricas. Os alunos são convidados a ler uma obra recente de David Brion Davis, um importante historiador da escravidão, e a comparar seus argumentos com os dados encontrados do banco de dados. Isso constitui a base para uma discussão sobre quais tipos de afirmações são mais difíceis de defender do que outras, e porque alguns tipos de dados são mais convincentes do que outros.

Resumen
Esta lección pone igual énfasis en la historia del comercio de esclavos trasatlántico, así como en el arte de formular argumentos históricos. Se les pide a los estudiantes leer una obra reciente de David Brion Davis, un importante historiador de la esclavitud y comparar sus argumentos con la evidencia de la base de datos. Esto crea la base para una discusión sobre cuales tipos de enunciados son más difíciles de defender que otros y por qué un tipo de evidencia resulta más convincente que otro.

fields.content:
Researching the Transatlantic Slave Trade (Download, PDF )
Author: Christine Kadonsky; David Eltis
Grade Level: 9th ? 12th grade
Course: World History; US History
Key Words:Abolition; Slave Trade; United States; World History; Primary Sources; Graph skills
Standards

Abstract
In this lesson, students will learn how to search The Trans--Atlantic Slave Trade Database. They will discover the scope of the slave trade over four centuries. Students will search the database to learn more about five noteworthy voyages. Students will review the African Names Database to learn the name of Africans liberated from ships attempting to trade illegally. By completing this lesson, students will have a better understanding how historians use databases and statistics to conduct historical research.

Os alunos pesquisarão o banco de dados para saber mais sobre cinco viagens notáveis. Ao completarem esta lição, eles terão uma melhor compreensão de como os historiadores utilizam os bancos de dados e as estatísticas para realizar pesquisas históricas.

fields.title: Introduction
fields.content:
Methodology 
Alex Borucki (University of California, Irvine), Greg O'Malley (University of California, Santa Cruz), 2018
Introduction 

The text that follows in each of the introductory sections is intended to be read in combination with the overview of the Transatlantic Slave Trade Database. Having emulated the format and methodology of the transatlantic database, wherever possible, here we only examine the sources, methods, and construction that are specific to the Intra-American Slave Trade Database. In most cases, the methodology, variable names, data codes, and user interfaces of each database are nearly identical and described thoroughly in the overview of the transatlantic database. What remains is to describe the origins of the intra-American database and explain its few distinctions in method and practice from the transatlantic precursor.

Whereas most twentieth-century slave trade scholarship focused on the Atlantic crossing, in the first decades of the twentieth-first century, historians working on disparate parts of the Americas increasingly document intra-American networks of forced migration, asserting their significance for both the African diaspora and the geopolitics of the Atlantic World. For example, O’Malley’s book, Final Passages: The Intercolonial Slave Trade of British America, demonstrates that hundreds of thousands of people who arrived in British American colonies from Africa quickly boarded new ships for intra-American voyages—both within British America and across imperial lines to French and Spanish colonies. Similarly, in the American Historical Review, Borucki, Eltis, and Wheat estimate that more than twenty-five percent of the two million Africans who arrived in the Spanish Americas, nearly 600,000 individuals, endured transshipment from other American colonies rather than being sent directly from Africa. Older historiographies exist on domestic slave trading in nineteenth-century Brazil and the United States but interest in those topics has also increased in the last two decades. The Intra-American Slave Trade Database seeks to pull data on all such forced migrations together. The consolidation of such information in a single database reveals patterns, connections, and entanglements previously hidden by language barriers and geographic specialization.

The Intra-American Slave Trade Database reveals the overwhelming importance and ubiquity of slave trading in the New World. It also extends the geographic coverage offered by the Transatlantic Slave Trade Database, as it adds nearly 11,000 slave voyages within the Americas stretching from Boston to Buenos Aires, and both the Atlantic and the Pacific littorals. This database offers basic demographic evidence to underlay examinations of when, where, and how African captives, and sometimes captives born in the Americas, continued their forced journeys within and across the European empires of the Americas as well as newly formed nations such as the United States and Brazil. Such information has the potential to enrich cultural studies of the African Diaspora with a clearer sense of the routes African women and men traveled to life and enslavement in various American locales. It also sheds light on lived experiences of captives, by adding complexity to our understanding of the duration of journeys in the slave trade, shipboard conditions, patterns of age and sex, and of course the horrific mortality of the traffic.

The new database also redraws the map of American slavery. If the launch of the online version of the Transatlantic Slave Trade Database in 2008 spotlighted the significance of Brazil as the most important broad region of slave disembarkation in the Atlantic slave trade (a fact previously underappreciated), the dominant pattern to emerge from this new intra-American database is the importance of the Spanish Americas as, probably, the second largest broad region of slave disembarkation in the Americas. Looking at the transatlantic traffic alone vastly understates the importance of Spanish territories to the history of slavery in the Americas, but the data contained here adds thousands of slave voyages from (mainly) Portuguese, British, and Dutch colonies to Spanish dominions, mostly in Cuba, Puerto Rico, Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela, and the Río de la Plata region. For those interested in the slave trade to the many Spanish colonies across the New World, it is imperative to use both the transatlantic and the intra-American databases, in order to examine the volume and routes of this traffic as well as the origins of African and African-descended captives.

The same is true for many colonies in other empires that were not the primary centers of slave exploitation. In the British case, for example, the transatlantic slave trade supplied most of the captives to major plantation zones, such as Barbados, Jamaica, South Carolina, and Virginia. But smaller colonies, and those less dependent on slave labor, tended to draw significant numbers of enslaved children, women, and men from intra-American routes of forced migration. As a result, those studying New York, the Bahamas, Massachusetts, or British Honduras will find as much (or more) relevant information in the intra-American as in the transatlantic database.

fields.title: Intra-American Database Essays
fields.content:
Essays
Alex Borucki (University of California, Irvine), Greg O'Malley (University of California, Santa Cruz), 2018

Patterns in the intercolonial slave trade across the Americas before the nineteenth century

The slave trade within the Americas, after the initial disembarkation of African captives in the New World, has received scant attention from historians, especially before the abolition of the transatlantic traffic. The article below examines such intra-American trafficking as an introduction to the launching of the The Intra-American Slave Trade Database, which aims to document evidence of slave voyages throughout the New World. This article does not provide statistics on this internal slave trade. Instead, we consolidate qualitative knowledge about these intercolonial slave routes. As the article focuses on the era prior to British and U.S. abolition of the transatlantic trade (1807-1808), we leave out the nineteenth-century domestic slave trades in the United States and Brazil to focus on survivors of the Atlantic crossing who endured subsequent forced movement within the Americas.

 

Gregory E. O'Malley and Alex Borucki, "Patterns in the intercolonial slave trade across the Americas before the nineteenth century," Tempo, 23 (May/Aug 2017): 315-338.

fields.title: Ensayos
fields.content:
Ensayos
Alex Borucki (Universidad de California, Irvine), Greg O'Malley (Universidad de California, Santa Cruz), 2018
Patrones de tráfico de esclavos intercolonial a través de las Américas antes del siglo XIX
El tráfico interno de esclavos en las Américas, después del desembarque inicial de africanos cautivos en el Nuevo Mundo, ha recibido poca atención de los historiadores, especialmente antes de la abolición del tráfico transatlántico. Este artículo, cuyo enlace está debajo, examina el tráfico interno de las Américas como una introducción al proyecto de la Base de Datos de Tráfico Intra-Americano, que pretende registrar evidencias de viages de esclavos dentro del Nuevo Mundo. En este artículo se consolidam conocimiento cualitativo sobre esas rutas intercoloniales de esclavos. Como el artículo se concentra en el período anterior a la abolición británica y estadounidense del tráfico transatlántico (1807-1808), no abordamos el tráfico doméstico de esclavos en los Estados Unidos ni en el Brasil. 
 
Gregory E. O'Malley and Alex Borucki, Patterns in the intercolonial slave trade across the Americas before the nineteenth century, Tempo, 23 (May/Aug 2017): 315-338
